thread.title: Matthew McConaughey says it’s time to ‘embrace’ Donald Trump | London Evening Standard
thread.title_full: Matthew McConaughey says it’s time to ‘embrace’ Donald Trump | London Evening Standard

author: Emma Powell
title: Matthew McConaughey says it’s time to ‘embrace’ Donald Trump | London Evening Standard
text:
Matthew McConaughey says it’s time to ‘embrace’ Donald Trump 
The actor said the US needs to be "constructive" with the President Thursday 2 February 2017 11:02 BST Click to follow Brexit white paper set to reveal Government's plan for leaving EU 
Matthew McConaughey has said it is time for the people of the US to “embrace” Donald Trump as President. 
Mr Trump has been scorned by many of McConaughey’s contemporaries, but the actor said it’s time to accept the fact and be “constructive” with the Republican. 
McConaughey made the comment during an interview on The Andrew Marr Show ahead of his new film Gold. 
Marr compared the characters and scenarios in the Stephen Gaghan directed film to the political climate in the US, and asked the Oscar-winning actor if it’s time for Hollywood and the cultural elite of America to “give the guy a break”. Donald Trump calls Madonna 'disgusting' in Fox interview 
McConaughey replied: “They don’t have a choice now. He’s our President. 
“It’s the most divisive inauguration we’ve ever had, but at the same time it’s time for us to embrace and shake hands with the fact and be constructive with him over the next four years. 
“Even those that strongly disagree with his principles and things he’s said and done, no matter how much you disagreed along the way it’s time to think of how constructive you can be. 
“He’s our President for the next four years, at least.” 
It comes days after Nicole Kidman encouraged people to “support” Mr Trump after he was sworn in. Read more Trump brands Madonna 'disgusting' and Saturday Night Live a 'disgrace' 
Kidman – who is a dual citizen of both the United States and Australia – said the public need to support the decision. 
“He’s now elected and we as a country need to support whoever is President because that is what the country is based on,” she told the BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire. 
“However that happened he’s there and let’s go.” 
Others stars including Madonna, Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus and Meryl Streep have all lambasted the new President. How the world’s newspapers reacted to Donald Trump’s inauguration How the world’s newspapers reacted to Donald Trump’s inauguration 1/11 
New leader: An arrangement of British newspapers show US President Donald Trump on the front pages the day after his inauguration Getty Images 2/11 
The New York Post quoted Mr Trump’s inaugural speech in which he promised to return power back to American voters. It said: “Power to you, the people.” New York Post 3/11 
The Washington Post ran with the headline: “Trump takes power: New president vows to end ‘American carnage’”. Washington Post 4/11 
France’s Le Figaro featured the billionaire businessman on the cover of its magazine edition, writing: “What if he did the job?” Le Figaro 
The headline of German newspaper Der Spiegel read: “The new world order – Trump’s game”. Der Spiegel 6/11 
The Daily Mail newspaper ran with the headline “I swear to be the People’s President” with a picture of Mr Trump taking the oath of office Daily Mail 
The Daily Mirror’s front page read: “Trump’s war on the world”. Daily Mirror 
"Trump unveils new era", read the frontpage of the Times 9/11 
The Independent's headline said: "So help us god" 10/11 
The Guardian referred to Mr Trump's pledge to "Put America first" 11/11 
The Telegraph referred to Mr Trump's pledge to "end American carnage"
